children.subject:
Personally, there isn’t much need to take DS major, CS courses are already able to cover the contents meaningful.
Another takeaway tip is that you could try MCB 160, the mol bio course adjusted specifically for neuro-emphasis MCB track which only requires general bio course (1A&L) and general physics (8A) as prerequisites. Start from that you may determine whether you would like to incline to bio side or comp side.
You could always just take the classes that interest you without worrying about adding a second major...or maybe there's a minor that better suits your interests?

Agree with Helix there, maybe not the best strategy for employment nor grad school. But personally, I think if you plan on devoting a lot of time to exploring another subfield, maybe make it your second major/minor just in case. Then if you happen to like that field more, you will have the option to focus on that field and pursue that as a career, and you will have something more concrete to show the employer/ grad school mentor than saying "I explored that field extensively during undergrad"

I'm almost finished with a double major in Civil Engineering and EECS.

Pros:

+ scholarship from CEE as part of an undergraduate research program

+ easier to know faculty (some who work in smart cities/AVs which is what I'm interested in), easier to get research experience

+ smaller major so a more tight-knit community

+ definitely catches eyes on resume (eventually did land an internship in autonomous vehicles)

Cons:

- Classes in both majors are difficult in their own ways

- Heavy workload is very difficult to balance (my GPA is not very high)

- A lot of grind-work for lower div prereqs because you're not gonna like every class in a major -- now double that

If I had to redo my Cal experience, I probably would not do the double major (probably one or the other). You basically have to take 4 techs every semester and it's very difficult to concentrate and do well in all of them.

From what I've heard, double majoring is pretty pointless, since grad schools or employers don't give it weight. If you want to explore another subfield for the passion of it, just take the classes you want.

(Not the Anon OP)
I am feeling that this refers to the fact that you could learn all of the required courses of DS major in CS major (regardless of DS C100 enforcement of C8 effective this fall). In this way, DS is a subset of CS.
I’ve heard of similar statements before, but this seems to be a very vague, not well defined common sense so I am not able to provide any citation source.
However, a strictly defined DS major should be the intersection of statistics and CS, so the statement able could be wrong under some different circumstances.

"Is it even worth to double in CS and data sci since they are pretty much the same thing?"

Citation needed

history.content:
My initial plan was to double in CS and cogsci, but after some thinking I realised that I'm not actually that interested in the Cogsci requirements like philosophy or social cognition. I only really wanted to learn about the biological and computational sides of the brain. I already took cogsci 1, am taking mcb 61 and plan to take cogsci 100(the cognitive neuroscience course). These are the bio related courses of the cog sci major. As for the computational side, I'm already taking those via CS like cs 188. So i was wondering whether it would be a better idea to double in CS and data sci with an emphasis on cognition because then I would be focusing on only the courses that interest me(neuroscience, ML, and cs). Any thoughts on this? Is it even worth to double in CS and data sci since they are pretty much the same thing?
Any advice or thoughts would be greatly appreciated, Thank You!
history.subject: advice on choosing 2nd major
